title: Amplitude Modulation (AM) Derivation

steps.title: Definition of Amplitude Modulation
steps.description: We start with the basic definition of modulation: multiplying a carrier signal by a message signal.
steps.explanation: Where A_c is carrier amplitude, m(t) is the normalized message signal, and f_c is the carrier frequency.

steps.title: Expand the AM Signal
steps.description: Distribute the carrier cosine term across the bracketed expression.
steps.equation: s_{AM}(t) = A_c \cos(2\pi f_c t) + A_c m(t) \cos(2\pi f_c t)
steps.explanation: This separates the carrier component from the modulated component.

steps.title: Identify Signal Components
steps.description: The signal consists of two parts: carrier and sidebands.
steps.equation: s_{AM}(t) = \underbrace{A_c \cos(2\pi f_c t)}_{\text{Carrier}} + \underbrace{A_c m(t) \cos(2\pi f_c t)}_{\text{Sidebands}}
steps.explanation: The first term is the unmodulated carrier. The second term creates upper and lower sidebands.

steps.title: Fourier Transform to Frequency Domain
steps.description: Taking the Fourier transform to analyze the spectrum.
steps.explanation: The carrier appears as impulses at ±f_c, and the message spectrum M(f) is translated to ±f_c.

steps.title: Power Distribution
steps.description: Calculate the power in carrier and sidebands.
steps.explanation: The total power is the sum of carrier power and sideband power. Sideband power depends on message signal power.

key_results: AM signal consists of carrier + two sidebands
assumptions: Carrier frequency f_c >> message bandwidth f_m
